lesson.title: A/B Test and Multivariate Test
lesson.summary: In this lesson, you will learn the A/B test, multivariate test, how to evaluate the test and respond to the test results.

concepts.title: A/B Test and Multivariate Test

atoms.text: # A/B Test and Multivariate Test

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 01 Introduction To Launching And Evaluating A-B And Multivariate Tests Video

atoms.text:
## Summary

Welcome to the final lesson: A/B and multivariate tests. In this lesson, we will cover how to choose appropriate tests for a situation, how to track data during a test, and how to evaluate test results for statistical significance.

concepts.title: Big Picture / Intuition

atoms.text: # Big Picture / Intuition

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 02 Big Picture Video

atoms.text:
## Summary
Experiments like A/B and multivariate tests allow product managers to know with confidence whether a new feature results in desired outcomes. Designing and launching tests is an important part of data-driven iterative design.

concepts.title: Lesson Outline

atoms.text: # Lesson Outline

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 03 Lesson Outline Video

atoms.text:
## Summary
In this lesson, we’ll first learn about A/B and multivariate experiments and the benefits and drawbacks of each type of test. Then we will talk about how and when to use each type of experiment.

In the second part of this lesson, we’ll discuss how to instrument and track user actions during tests.

In the third part of this lesson, we’ll discuss how to place participants into test and control groups to ensure an unbiased sample, so that the results of an experiment can be trusted.

Finally, we’ll learn how to analyze test results to ensure findings are statistically significant.

## Lesson objective
At the end of the lesson, you will be able to
- Explain the benefits and drawbacks of A/B testing
- Explain the benefits and drawbacks of multivariate testing 
- Determine what type of test is appropriate given feature(s) of interest
- Determine what user actions should be tracked during A/B and multivariate tests
- Explain methods to create unbiased control and test groups of users
- Apply the correct statistical methods to explain the difference between the experimental and control group data and make a decision

concepts.title: Benefits and Drawbacks of Different Tests

atoms.text: # Benefits and Drawbacks of Different Test
## A/B and Multivariate Test

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 04 Benefits And Drawbacks Of A-B Testing Video Part 1

atoms.text: Error in the video: in the multivariate testing example, the design shown at the top right corner should have a dark blue bar, not a pink bar.

## Summary
### A/B test
An A/B test is an experiment to seeing if a *single change* has an effect compared to what is currently in place. 
An A/B test works in four steps: 
1. Decide what change you want to test. 
2. Decide which group of users will see the control and which group of users will see the test. 
3. Run the experiment. You want the experiment to run long enough that enough people can see it.
4. Measure the results and see if the experiment results in KPI improvement. 

### Multivariate tests
Multivariate tests follow the same steps of an A/B test in deciding what to test, making user groups, running an experiment, and measuring results. 

However, a multivariate test can test *more than one change* at once.
The multiple changes a product manager can test takes three main forms:

- Test a range: any variable that goes from a low number to a higher one.
- Test many, *totally different* versions of a feature or UI. 
- Test variations of a design by only *changing one element or a few elements* at a time.

To calculate how many tests one has, you need to *multiply the number of options in each testing element*. In the video, there are two testing elements and 3 options for each element (including the original version). So 3 options for the first testing element times 3 options for the second testing element (3*3), which gives 9 tests including the control (the original design).
## Benefits and Drawbacks

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 05 Benefits And Drawbacks Of A-B Testing Video Part 2

atoms.text:
## Benefits and drawbacks of A/B tests
- Benefit
 - Need fewer users to get statistically significant results since there aren't many test groups.

- Drawbacks 
 - Can only test one change at a time
 - Don’t have the ability to see how different changes interact together

## Benefits and drawbacks of multivariate tests
- Benefits
 - Allow testing many different variations at once
 - Show how different changes work together and interact

- Drawbacks
 - Need enough users in each group to show statistical significance
 - Running a large number of tests, including sorting users randomly into the many variations, can be difficult

Whether an A/B or multivariate test is used, product managers gain insight from experiments as to whether their proposed changes will have the hypothesized effect. This makes experiments an important tool in the product manager toolkit.

## New terms
- **A/B test:** An experiment to seeing if a *single change* has an effect compared to what is currently in place. 
- **Multivariate test:** An experiment to see the effects of a changes of multiple variables, including how the variables interact with each other.


## Further research

- *The Definitive Guide to Multivariate and A/B Testing*
https://www.invespcro.com/blog/multivariate-ab-testing-guide/

- *Multivariate Testing vs A/B Testing*
https://www.optimizely.com/optimization-glossary/multivariate-test-vs-ab-test/

concepts.title: Benefits and Drawbacks of Different Test Quizzes

atoms.text: # Benefits and Drawbacks of Different Test Quizzes

complex_prompt.text: Match the scenario with the best fit method of testing

correct_answer.text: A data product manager wants to know if showing the number of loyalty points that will be earned to the customer during checkout will increase completed purchases
A data product manager wants to know what discount level (from 0-20%) results in the most customers choosing to purchase an annual over a monthly subscription.

answers.text: A data product manager wants to know what discount level (from 0-20%) results in the most customers choosing to purchase an annual over a monthly subscription.
A data product manager wants to know if showing the number of loyalty points that will be earned to the customer during checkout will increase completed purchases

atoms.title: Benefits and Drawbacks of A/B and Multivariate Testing

question.prompt: Which of the following are true statements about the benefits and drawbacks of A/B and/or multivariate tests?

answers.text: A/B test allows product managers to test many changes at once
Multivariate test allows product managers to see how different changes impact each other
Multivariate test doesn't require as many users to show statistical significance from a small effect size
A/B and multivariate test both allow product managers to measure the impact of a product change on user conversion

question.prompt: A product manager wants to make 4 changes to a feature's design (the color of the page, the color of the submit button, the picture at the top of the page, and the word on the submit button). For each change, there are 2 new options (different than the current design). How many different test designs will the product manager have during a multivariate experiment?

answers.text: 8 test versions, including the control
12 test versions, including the control
36 test versions, including the control
81 test versions, including the control

concepts.title: Exercise 1: Select Between A/B and Multivariate Tests

atoms.text: #  Exercise 1: Select Between A/B and Multivariate Tests

## Instruction

You've been called in as a consultant by two businesses, business A and business B. With your testing expertise, they want to know if they should be running an A/B test or a multivariate test. Read the scenarios below and explain whether an A/B or multivariate test would be a better testing choice for the businesses.

atoms.title: Scenario #1

question.text:
Business A has a page accessible only to existing users. Now they have a new and different design for the page to push these existing users to take the desired action. They have a variety of colors and images they would love to test on the page. They do note that the business is fairly new and has a small number of users right now. 

Should they use an A/B test or a multivariate test for the new design of the page? Why?

atoms.title: Scenario #2

question.text:
Business B is a gallery with a landing page for *new users* that shows several pictures of artwork in a grid. They get a lot of traffic and are trying to figure out how many and which pictures to display on the page (both across and down the page) to convince users that the site is useful without overwhelming them. They want to know the ideal number of pictures (and which pictures) will prompt the most new users to click through for more information about the business.

Should they use an A/B test or a multivariate test for the new design of the page? Why?

concepts.title: Solution: Select Between A/B and Multivariate Tests Exercise

atoms.text: #  Solution: Select Between A/B and Multivariate Tests Exercise

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 06 Choosing Between A-B And Multivariate Tests Exercise Solution Video

atoms.text:
## Summary

### Scenario 1 : 

The business should use an A/B test on the new design of the page. With a small number of users, it would take a long time to receive enough visitors to gain conclusive evidence on the best direction to take the page if they presented a multivariate test with many colors and images. Even though they could run a multivariate test in the sense of testing multiple variations of the page, the business should stick with an A/B test given the traffic the page in question receives.

### Scenario 2:
The business should use a multivariate test on the design of the page. With a large number of new users landing on the page, the business has the traffic to come to a conclusion even when testing multiple options and variations. The business can use dynamic tools to adjust the number of pictures shown on the site to determine the number of pictures both across and down the page that result in the best click through. As a next step, they can also test different images in different spots to conclude which generates the most visitor interest.

concepts.title: Track User Actions During Testing

atoms.text: # Track User Actions During Testing

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 07 Track User Actions During Testing Video 1

atoms.text:
## Summary
### Track user data
When launching an experiment, it is important to track user activity and user characteristics.

It is always helpful to track user actions on an experiment page to know *what they did and when they did it* during the interaction with the experiment page.

It is also important to know *how much time* a user spends on the experiment page, perhaps measured by tracking user entry to the page and the time of user exit.

In addition to user actions, it is also helpful to collect information that may *vary about a user from visit to visit* such as device and OS.

### Instrumentation
Some instrumentation that needs to be in place for experiments is different than that normally considered in feature and funnel analysis.

Product managers do not always run experiments on all users, but may *focus on a particular type of users*. This means you need to instrument and collect information on the right type of users and ensure that they are part of the experiment.

It is vitally important to track *which test state a user is assigned.* This enables you to analyze the difference in results among experiment groups and to ensure the same test state is shown to the same user until the experiment is over.

The final thing to track during an experiment is the *conversion rate*. It is the percentage of users who successfully performed the desired action in each experiment group. The key to choosing the correct conversion rate is to choose one that relates to the important, long term impact you wish your experiment to drive. This may often be a product or feature KPI.

## New terms
- **Conversion rate:** For an experiment, the conversion rate is the percentage of users who performed the desired action out of all users in a test group.

## Further research

- *Experimental Design & How to avoid blowing everything up*
https://medium.com/analytics-and-data/experimental-design-how-to-avoid-blowing-everything-up-c7ec93ad8cc8

concepts.title: Track User Actions During Testing Quizzes

atoms.text: # Track User Actions During Testing Quizzes

question.prompt: As a data product manager, you are testing a new feature that allows users to change the product website color scheme to "dark mode." Which of the below metrics would be important to track when running the test? (Select all that apply)

answers.text: The time a user uses the feature
The device each user is on
The percent of users who used the dark mode feature
The conversion rate (those who see the feature and use it)
Which users are exposed to the dark mode feature

atoms.title: Tracking User Test State Exposure

question.prompt: Why is it important to track to which test state a user was assigned?

answers.text: To be able to calculate the conversion rate per test state
To ensure the same user never sees the same experience twice
To track everything possible about the experiment in case the data is needed in the future
To measure whether users choose the test over the control state

concepts.title: Exercise 2: Track User Actions During Testing

atoms.text: # Exercise 2: Track User Actions During Testing

## Instruction

Now the two businesses,  business A and business B need help in deciding what data to track during the experiments. Read the scenarios again below and explain what data should be tracked if it isn't already. Specifically call out what data will help the business determine if a test condition wins over the control.

atoms.title: Scenario #1

question.text:
Business A has a page accessible only to existing users. They have a new and different design for the page to use a specific feature that allows user to link their social accounts. They have a variety of colors and images they would love to test on the page. They do note that the business is fairly new and has a small number of users right now. Given your advice, they'll be running an **A/B test** with the existing design and one version of the new design being shown to different users.

Which data should be tracked on the page if it isn't already? Which data will determine the winning condition of the page?

atoms.title: Scenario #2

question.text:
Business B is a gallery with a landing page for *new users* that shows a number of pictures of artwork. They get a lot of traffic and are trying to figure out how many and which pictures to display on the page to convince users the site is useful without overwhelming them. They want to know the ideal number of pictures (and which pictures) will prompt the most *new users* to click through for more information about the business. Given your advice, they'll be running a **multivariate test** that shows a different number of pictures and different pieces of artwork on the new visitor landing page.

Which data should be tracked on the page if it isn't already? Which data will determine the winning condition of the page?

concepts.title: Solution: Track User Actions During Testing Exercise

atoms.text: # Solution: Track User Actions During Testing Exercise

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 08 Track User Actions During Testing Exercise Solution Video

atoms.text:
## Summary

### Scenario 1 : 

- Business A needs to track the number of unique visitors to the page where they will be testing the new design. 
- They will need to track whether a user sees the control or the experimental design on the page. 
- They will also likely want to track the device and browser that the visitor is using in case the designs perform differently across device types. 
- Finally, to know which page is more effective, they will need to track whether the visitor takes the desired action of using the social linking feature 

### Scenario 2:

- The business will need to track the number of pictures, which pieces of artwork, and in which order, are shown to the visitors. 
- The business will also need to track visitors (such as by dropping a cookie) to ensure the visitors are first-time visitors since that is the audience in question. 
- The business will want to track device type and OS in case different designs do better on different screen sizes.
- Finally, given that the business has stated its goal is to prompt more visitors to click through the landing page to learn more information about the business, the business will need to track whether a specific visitor clicks through for more information in order to determine the winning condition.

concepts.title: Ensure Unbiased Control & Test Groups

atoms.text: # Ensure Unbiased Control & Test Groups

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 09 Ensuring Unbiased Control & Test Groups Video

atoms.text:
## Summary
When running experiments, you must make sure that users in the control and the test/experiment group share the same characteristics. That way, you can ensure the differences among experiment groups is caused by the change of the product, not by different user characteristics.

First, you need to determine what type of user you are testing and make sure these target users are put into both the control and experiment groups.

In addition to everyone being a target user, you need to make sure other user characteristics such as age, race, income are balanced between the control and experiment groups.

A great way to get a balance of user characteristics among the groups is to randomize who is in the control and who is in the experiment group.

If you are performing extensive multivariate testing, the best way is to invest in a framework that assigns users randomly to groups based on the conversion rates seen by each group to that point. Using an established framework or creating one based on strong data science principles can decrease the number of users required to perform the test.

## New terms

- **Control group:** The group of users in an experiment for whom the user experience is not changed. 
- **Test/experiment group:** Group or groups of users for whom the user experience is changed in some way during an experiment.

## Further research

- *Adaptive Experimentation Platform*
https://ax.dev/

- *Arrival Rate Bias in A/B Testing*
https://towardsdatascience.com/arrival-rate-bias-ab-testing-1-d291ae9d0cab

- *What is a Control Group and Why is it Important in Testing?*
https://clevertap.com/blog/what-is-a-control-group/

concepts.title: Ensure Unbiased Control & Test Groups Quizzes

atoms.text: # Ensure Unbiased Control & Test Groups Quizzes

atoms.title: Balancing User Types Among Control and Test Groups

question.prompt: Why is it important to achieve balance among user types in the test and control groups?

answers.text: By randomizing users sent into the test and control groups, you can achieve a balance of user features in the test and control groups
To ensure that any difference in user conversion rate is not from a difference between the users, but caused by a different between the test and control states
To ensure there aren't too many users in the test or control groups
To ensure you're targeting the right type of user for the test you are running

question.prompt: If you randomize the users placed into the "A" (control) or "B" (test) group, which of the following user characteristics would you expect to be balanced between the groups?

answers.text: The percent of users in each group who are male
The percent of users who convert
The number of users in the control and test group
The percent of users in each group who use the product daily

concepts.title: Exercise 3: Ensure Unbiased Control & Test Groups

atoms.text: # Exercise 3: Ensure Unbiased Control & Test Groups

## Instruction

The two businesses,  business A and business B need more help from you. With your testing expertise, you let them know whether they would be better running an A/B test or a multivariate test and what data to track. Now the business needs help in deciding which users to place into control and test groups for their experiments. Read the scenarios again below and explain how to create unbiased control and test groups for these scenarios. Specifically call out what user elements might be important to balance among control and test groups.

atoms.title: Scenario #1

question.text:
Business A has a page accessible only to **existing users**. They have a new and different design for the page to push these existing users to take a desired action. They have a variety of colors and images they would love to test on the page. They do note that the business is fairly new and has a small number of users right now. The business will be running an A/B test. Given your advice, they'll be running an A/B test with the existing design and one version of the new design being shown to different users.


How should users be separated into control and test groups? Are there differences in the type of user that should be balanced among control and test groups?

atoms.title: Scenario #2

question.text:
Business B is a gallery with a landing page for **new users** that shows a number of pictures of artwork. They get a lot of traffic and are trying to figure out how many and which pictures to show on the page to convince users the site is useful without overwhelming them. They want to know the ideal number of pictures (and which pictures) will prompt the most new users to click through for more information about the business. Given your advice, they'll be running a multivariate test that shows a different number of pictures and different pieces of artwork on the new visitor landing page.


How should users be separated into control and test groups? Are there differences in the type of user that should be balanced among control and test groups?

concepts.title: Solution: Ensure Unbiased Control & Test Groups Exercise

atoms.text: # Solution: Ensure Unbiased Control & Test Groups Exercise

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 10 Ensuring Unbiased Control & Test Groups Exercise Solution Video

atoms.text:
## Summary

### Scenario 1 : 

Since the business is working with *existing users*, they should be able to easily create an unbiased test and control group based on the information they have on their users. 

First, they should randomly assign users to either the test or control condition. It would be most helpful if a user in one group sees either "A" or "B" no matter how or where they log in. They should also check to ensure the *user characteristics* remain relatively *balanced* between control and test groups. 

By using random assignment, it is likely that devices, operating systems/browsers, and even user types (newer vs. established users; frequent vs. infrequent users) would be relatively similar across both groups. However, the business should confirm that these user characteristics are roughly similar across both groups to prevent unintentional bias.


### Scenario 2:

The business should randomly place new visitors into control and test groups. They can help ensure the visitors are truly new by dropping a cookie on all visitors and only showing putting users into an experiment or control group if they do not yet have a visitor's cookie. As they are performing a multivariate test, the business may want to use a framework for multivariate testing that assigns users at different rates based on the impact seen of different designs. 

As business A, if they randomly assign users, they should confirm that user characteristics that might impact the effect of the experiments are balanced among the control and experiment groups. For example, the business should ensure that each experiment has a balanced number of users on different devices/OS/browsers.  Since the business is testing designs with first-time users, they won't have much more information about the users to differentiate upon. If they randomly assign users, other user characteristics that might impact the effect of the experiments should balance out among the control and experiment groups.

concepts.title: Calculate & Respond to Test Results

atoms.text: # Calculate & Respond to Test Results

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 11 Calculating & Responding To Test Results  Video

atoms.text:
## Summary
The results experiments can be evaluated by a **T-Test**. A T-test compares the means of two groups to see whether the difference in the means is large enough that it is probably not due to random chance. 

In the case of an A/B or multivariate test, the T-test helps us understand whether any differences observed in the conversion rate are significant and are likely due to the change we made.

To properly evaluate the results, there are 3 steps that need to be taken *before using the T-test*.

- **Step 1: state the null hypothesis.**
The null hypothesis represents the idea that the control state is not different from a test state, which is what we want to *reject*.
A generic null hypothesis would be: customers *convert the same* with the test state compared to the control state. 

- **Step 2: state the alternative hypothesis.**
The alternative hypothesis is the one you want to *accept*. A generic alternative hypothesis would be: customers will *convert differently* with this change.

- **Step 3: set a confidence threshold.** Product managers almost universally user a *95% confidence level*, which means a 95% chance that the result appears statistically valid and a 5% chance that the result is an error.

> A higher confidence level means you won’t get as many *false positives* that declare your experiment likely has an effect when it doesn’t. However, a higher confidence level also means you may declare a test to have not had an effect when it actually does have a weak one. Setting a confidence interval before performing a test ensures that you are not tempted later to lower your confidence threshold to make your results statistically significant.

Once the hypothesis and confidence threshold for an experiment have been set, you can move to:
- **Step 4: run the A/B or multivariate experiment.** 
- **Step 5: perform a T-test.**  After you get the result from your experiment, you need to perform a T-test to see if the differences you see in the experiment are significant. To perform a T-test, you will need to know:
 - The number of users in the control group and in each test group
 - The number of conversions in each group
 - The confidence threshold from step 3
 - Decide if the T-test is a one-tailed or two-tailed test. A two-tailed test means you assume the experiment conversion rate is different from the control, maybe *worse OR better*.

To see whether the results are significant, you need to compare if the *p-value* from the T-test is less than a threshold. Without going into too many details, if the confidence threshold you choose is 95%, and it is a two-tailed test, you need to compare the p-value against 0.025. When the p-value is *less* than 0.025, the null hypothesis of *experiment and control have the same conversion rate* can be rejected. In other words, the difference in the control and experiment conversion rates can be considered significant at 95% confidence. 

- **Step 6: take action.** If your experiment finds the change to be helpful and the results are statistically significant, you can expand the test condition to more or all of users. If the change doesn’t have the desired effect or the results aren’t significant, you should keep experimenting.
## Responding to Test Results Walkthrough

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 12 Calculating & Responding To Test Results  Walkthrough

atoms.text:
## Summary

In this experiment, the test group made slightly more purchases per user than the control group. We don't know if this difference is due to random chance so we need to use the T-test to see if the differences in conversion rate are larger enough (significant).
- Step 1, the null hypothesis: there is *no difference* in the purchase rate between users in the control and test groups. This is what we want to *reject*.
- Step 2, the alternative hypothesis: there is *a difference* in the purchase rate between the test and control groups. This is what we want to *accept.*
- Step 3, confidence threshold: 95%
- Step 4, A/B experiment has been done
- Step 5, perform the T-test. Insert the data from the A/B experiment and set it to be a two-tailed test since the test group can convert *higher or lower* than the control group.

From the T-test calculator, we see the p-value is, which is greater than 0.025. This means we cannot reject our null hypothesis that the test and control groups have the same rate of purchase. In other words, the purchase rate from the test group and the control group are not significantly different.

In this example, we see if the results of an A/B test were statistically significant by comparing the control “A” to the experiment “B”. For a multivariate test, you would compare the control “A” to experiments “B” and then “A” to “C”  and “A” to “D”and so on to see if any test states have a significant effect.

## New terms
- **Alternative hypothesis:** Hypothesis in testing that is contrary to the null hypothesis. Usually the alternative hypothesis is that any differences observed are due to a real effect of the experiment.
- **Null hypothesis:** Hypothesis in testing that there is no difference between test groups, and that any differences observed are due to error or random chance.
- **P value:** The value that indicates the probability of obtaining results as extreme as the observed results of a statistical hypothesis test, assuming that the null hypothesis is correct. A smaller p-value means the evidence in favor of the alternative hypothesis is stronger.
- **T-Test:** A type of statistical analysis that compares the means of two groups to see whether the difference in the means is large enough that it is probably not due to random chance.

## Further research

- *Guidelines For Ab Testing*
https://robinsones.github.io/Guidelines-for-AB-Testing/

- *Statistical Significance in A/B Testing – a Complete Guide*
http://blog.analytics-toolkit.com/2017/statistical-significance-ab-testing-complete-guide/

- *When To Do Multivariate Tests Instead of A/B/n Tests*
https://cxl.com/blog/multivariate-tests/

concepts.title: Calculate & Respond to Test Results Quizzes

atoms.text: # Calculate & Respond to Test Results Quizzes

question.prompt: Select all the statements that are true about T-Tests as used in product management when evaluating the results of an A/B test or comparing the results of different multivariate test states.

answers.text: Most product managers use two-tailed T tests as their experiments can make conversion rates go up and down
Most product managers use a 98% confidence interval, as this is the same standard that many medical studies use
Most product managers look for a p-value below .025 to indicate statistical significance of test results
If a t-test's results are statistically significant, this means the difference in the conversion rates between the test and control state will definitely continue if the test is expanded

question.prompt:
Read the test results for a new landing page, should the product manager expand the test state to all users? You may use an online A/B Testing calculator. 

5,000 users in the control state and 5,000 users in the test state
400 first time visitors in control state converted from visitor to registered user
500 first time visitors in the test state converted from visitor to registered user

answers.text: No, the product manager does not have statistically significant results with a p-value of above .025; the product manager needs to run more tests and experiments
No, the product manager does not have statistically significant results with a p-value of .025; the product manager needs to run more tests and experiments
Yes, the product manager has statistically significant results with a p-value of .025; the new landing page will likely increase conversion
Yes, the product manager has statistically significant results with a p-value below .025; the new landing page will likely increase conversion

question.prompt:
Read the test results for a new landing page, should the product manager expand the test state to all users?

8,000 users in the control state and 8,000 users in the test state
1,500 first time visitors in control state converted from visitor to registered user
500 first time visitors in the test state converted from visitor to registered user

answers.text: Yes, the results are statistically significant so the test state should be expanded to all product users
No, the results are not statistically significant; the product manager needs to run more tests and experiments
No, the results are statistically significant, but the conversion rate is lower in the test state so the test state should not be expanded to all users.

concepts.title: Exercise 4: Calculate & Respond to Test Results

atoms.text: # Exercise 4: Calculate & Respond to Test Results

## Instruction

A website launched a classic A/B test of its landing page. For about half the users, the original landing page was shown. For about half the users, a new design was shown but still had the same call to action, to subscribe to a newsletter.

The data that they provided contains information from the A/B test. In the data, you'll find a column with user IDs. The timestamp column represents when the user landed on the home page. You'll also find a "page" column that shows whether the user was shown the new, test page ("new_page") or the old, control page ("old_page"). The column "converted" shows whether a user subscribed to the newsletter ("1") or did not subscribe to the newsletter ("0").

 Analyze the data and answer the following questions. Click [here](https://video.udacity-data.com/topher/2020/July/5efcf235_l5-exercise4/l5-exercise4.csv) to download data.

1. Calculate the number of users in the test and control group 
2. Calculate the number of conversions in the test and control group
3. Based on the numbers produced in question 1 and 2, using a 2-sided T-test and the statistical significance calculator of your choice, are the test results significant at a 95% confidence level? How do you know?
4. Should the landing page be rolled out to all users? Why or why not?

atoms.title: Reflect

question.text: Use the space below to record your answers.

concepts.title: Solution: Calculate & Respond to Test Results Exercise

atoms.text: # Solution: Calculate & Respond to Test Results Exercise

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 13 Calculating & Responding To Test Results  Exercise Solution Video

atoms.text:
## Summary

#### 1) Calculate the number of users in the test and control group 

To calculate the number of users in the test group, count the number of unique user IDs associated with the new landing page. There are **146,317 unique users** in the **test** group and **146,265 unique users** in the **control** group. If you got **147,239 users** remember that you need to count the number of unique users, not the number of times any person visited the new test landing or old control page.

#### 2) Calculate the number of conversions in the test and control group

By counting the number of "converted = 1" when landing page = "new_page" or landing page = "old_page" , you will know the number of conversions (i.e. the number of times users subscribed to the newsletter) in the test and control groups. For the **test** group, there were **17,498 conversions**. For the **control group**, there were **17,739 conversions**.

#### 3) Based on the the numbers produced in question 1 and 2, using a 2-sided T test and the statistical significance calculator of your choice, are the test results significant at a 95% confidence level? How do you know?

Using a two-sided T test at a 95% confidence interval finds the results of the test are not significant. We know the results are not significant because the **p-value** generated is **.9199** which is larger than the p-value of .025. The large p-value indicates that the difference in conversion between the control and test group is not significant at a 95% confidence level in a two-sided T test. An image of the p-value calculation from an online statistical significance calculator is included below for review.

#### 4) Should the landing page be rolled out to all users? Why or why not?

The landing page should not necessarily be rolled out to all users as the results of the test are not significant. When results are not significant that means the test condition did not result in a statistically significant increase in conversions, which means any difference between the two landing pages is more likely due to random chance than to the differences between the two pages. This means the new test landing page cannot be said with confidence to lead more users to sign up for the newsletter. The website should continue to test different landing pages to see if they can generate a significant test result that shows higher conversion in the test condition.

atoms.caption: By entering the number of unique visitors and the number of conversions for the control and test landing pages, statistical significance calculators can predict whether the experienced difference in conversion rate is likely to be significant.
atoms.alt: Image of statistical significance calculator showing a p value of .9199

concepts.title: Lesson Conclusion

atoms.text: # Lesson Conclusion

atoms.title: ND030 C3 L5 14 Lesson Conclusion

atoms.text:
## Summary
Congratulations! You have just finished the sixth and final lesson.

In this lesson, we first learned about the difference between an A/B test and a multivariate test. We also learned the benefits and drawbacks of each type of test, and which test would be the best for different situations.

In the second part of the lesson, we covered how to track user actions and discussed the importance of instrumentation throughout an entire experiment.

In the third part of the lesson, we talked about the importance of recruiting test participants in a way that prevents bias in the results.

Finally, we discussed how to interpret the results of a test by performing a T-test to show the statistical significance of any observed effect. We also learned whether product managers should expand an experiment or revisit their ideas based on the test results.

## Glossary

- **A/B test:** An experiment to seeing if a *single change* has an effect compared to what is currently in place. 
- **Alternative hypothesis:** Hypothesis in testing that is contrary to the null hypothesis. Usually the alternative hypothesis is that any differences observed are due to a real effect of the experiment.
- **Control group:** The group of users in an experiment for whom the user experience is not changed. 
- **Conversion rate:** For an experiment, the conversion rate is the percentage of users who performed the desired action out of all users in a test group.
- **Multivariate test:** An experiment to see the effects of a changes of multiple variables, including how the variables interact with each other.
- **Null hypothesis:** Hypothesis in testing that there is no difference between test groups, and that any differences observed are due to error or random chance.
- **P value:** The value that indicates the probability of obtaining results as extreme as the observed results of a statistical hypothesis test, assuming that the null hypothesis is correct. A smaller p-value means the evidence in favor of the alternative hypothesis is stronger.
- **Test/experiment group:** Group or groups of users for whom the user experience is changed in some way during an experiment.
- **T-Test:** A type of statistical analysis that compares the means of two groups to see whether the difference in the means is large enough that it is probably not due to random chance.


## Further reading

- *Building a Culture of Experimentation*
https://hbr.org/2020/03/productive-innovation

- *How to Build an Experimentation Culture*
https://taplytics.com/blog/how-to-build-an-experimentation-culture/

- *Trustworthy Online Controlled Experiments: A Practical Guide to A/B Testing*
https://experimentguide.com/
